header.title: How to use the CG-2 parser vislcg

section.title: How to use the vislcg parser
Basic usage
section.p: The command line looks like this (for sme, supposing you stand in the sme directory):
section.source: sme$ cat sometext.txt | preprocess --abbr=bin/abbr.txt | lookup -flags mbTT bin/sme.fst | ../script/lookup2cg | vislcg --grammar=src/sme-dis.rle | less

section.title: Flags and their use
section.p: The vislcg program contains 18 flags, or usage options. A list of the flags may be obtained by writing the following command:
i.e., by using the flag --help. The most relevant flags for our use are the following:

dl.dd: This flag selects the grammar file. The "=" symbol is optional.
This flag sets the number of CONSTRAINT sections that are applied. In this way it is possible to study the effects of one rule set at a time.
This flag tells the parser to include information of what constraint rules are invoked in each concrete case. The flag is crucial for studying the effects of the different rules.
The flag --minimal is used together with the flag --trace. With this flag only the line number of the rule is given. Without the --minimal flag, the parser also lists the rule in question.

section.title: For reference: Tapanainen's original CG-2 parser
section.p: Tapanainen's original CG-2 parser mdis is available from Connexor. A copy of the parser is available for staff and students on the computer of the ling.dept at the U of Helsinki, at ~tapanain/conexor/mdis/bin/. The parser cannot be used outside this computer.
The CG-2 parser is actually two different CG-2 parsers (Tap96 mentions 4 more parsers, this information is obsolete):

dl.dd: mapping and disambiguation, but with id numbers of the rules.

section.title: The flags
section.p: This list given here is not complete, but includes only relevant flags. For a full list, see Tap96.

dl.dd: obligatorily for parsing (note the symbol "=*, in Tap96 this is still not included)
sets the number (n) of CONSTRAINT sections. By default, all sections are applied.
the parser does not apply rules

section.p: Thus, CG-2 differs from vislcg, that consists of only one parser (vislcg), but has more flags (also more flags than CG-2).
